I found my strength to perform well in education, and my results were satisfactory before secondary education and attempted three times to pass the exam. I did not know what was wrong with me and was in jeopardy with my family and surroundings.
Then I came into higher education in the Uk and sometimes later discovered that the Brain tumour was the reason for not remembering things and other complications. Then I came into higher education in the Uk and sometimes later discovered that the Brain tumour was the reason for not remembering things and other complications.   I took a long break and started my education again as I was unsatisfied with my situation. Although that was laughter for many around me, I did not listen to them. Completed my BSc in engineering and Master of research with first class. Later found my saviour Prof. Adrian Hopgood to finish my PhD in AI.
I have always struggled throughout my life being an introvert, and due to my health, I suffer from many other disabilities. Did not get a job with an interview. Employers intend to misjudge me for my neurodiversity and other disabilities; even holding a Doctorate, my success in securing a job is limited. The interview process and the experience are not suitable for me, and it is very stressful.
Therefore, I have come up with the idea to form the Neurodivergent Business Consortium (NBC) and the first person I named Cora Burke, to join this initiative. Together we are developing initiatives (brainchild) to help people with neurodiversity.

In today's competitive market, where consumers have countless choices, brand engagement has become a pivotal factor for businesses. It distinguishes brands in crowded markets, creates loyal customer bases, and enhances overall customer experience, making it a crucial element for long-term business success. While brand engagement may not be universally necessary, it plays a crucial role in driving business success, customer loyalty, and competitive advantage in many industries.
Understanding Brand Engagement
A. Definition and Components of Brand Engagement


Brand engagement encompasses the development of an emotional connection between a brand and its audience. This connection is built through various components, including:


Emotional connection: Brands strive to evoke emotions such as joy, trust, or excitement in their customers, fostering a deeper bond.

Customer interaction: It involves meaningful interactions between the brand and its customers, whether through social media engagement, customer service interactions, or experiential marketing.
Brand loyalty: Successful brand engagement results in customer loyalty, where individuals consistently choose a particular brand over its competitors, often due to the emotional connection and positive experiences they've had.



B. Differentiation from Other Marketing Concepts

Brand engagement differs from other marketing concepts such as brand awareness and customer satisfaction in its focus and outcomes:
	
Brand awareness primarily concerns making consumers aware of a brand's existence and offerings, whereas brand engagement emphasizes fostering a deeper connection beyond mere recognition.
Customer satisfaction revolves around meeting customer expectations and delivering quality products or services, whereas brand engagement aims to go beyond satisfaction to create loyal advocates who actively engage with and promote the brand.



 
Arguments Against the Necessity of Brand Engagement
 
A. Industry-specific Relevance


Commodities and Low-engagement Products: In industries where products are perceived as commodities or low-involvement items, the necessity of brand engagement may be questioned. Consumers may prioritize convenience or price over brand loyalty.

B2B Markets: In business-to-business (B2B) markets, where purchasing decisions are often based on rational factors like cost-effectiveness and functionality, the emotional connection fostered by brand engagement may have less impact.

B. Cost and Resource Implications

Small Businesses and Start-ups: For small businesses and start-ups with limited budgets and resources, investing in extensive brand engagement initiatives may not be feasible. They may prioritize immediate revenue-generating activities over long-term brand-building efforts.
Return on Investment Concerns: There may be concerns about the tangible return on investment (ROI) of brand engagement strategies, especially in industries or situations where the effects are difficult to measure or where results may take time to materialize.

C. Alternative Strategies

Price Competition: Some argue that in highly price-sensitive markets, competing solely on price may be more effective than investing in brand engagement efforts. Consumers may prioritize cost savings over brand loyalty.
Product Innovation: Instead of focusing on building brand engagement, businesses may opt to differentiate themselves through continuous product innovation, providing unique features or benefits that attract customers without necessarily relying on emotional connections.

Portfolio allocation refers to the process of distributing an investment portfolio across different asset classes, such as stocks, bonds, and real estate, to achieve a balance between risk and return. Portfolio allocation refers to the process of distributing an investment portfolio across different asset classes, such as stocks, bonds, and real estate, to achieve a balance between risk and return.  Risk tolerance: Investors with a higher risk tolerance may allocate more of their portfolio to high-risk, high-return assets like stocks, while investors with a lower risk tolerance may prefer lower-risk, lower-return assets like bonds. Investment goals: The goals an investor has for their portfolios, such as long-term growth or income generation, can also influence portfolio allocation. For example, an investor seeking long-term growth may allocate more to stocks, while an investor seeking income may allocate more to bonds. Time horizon: The time horizon an investor has for their portfolio can also impact portfolio allocation. A longer time horizon may allow for a more aggressive allocation to stocks, while a shorter time horizon may call for a more conservative allocation to lower-risk assets. Market conditions: Market conditions, such as the current economic environment, interest rates, and the performance of specific sectors, can also influence portfolio allocation. For example, a favourable economic environment may lead to a higher allocation to stocks, while a weaker economy may lead to a higher allocation to bonds. Diversification: Diversification is the practice of spreading investments across multiple assets to minimize risk. Investors may allocate their portfolios to a mix of asset classes, sectors, and geographic regions to achieve diversification. Tax considerations: Tax considerations may also impact portfolio allocation. For example, investors may allocate more to tax-advantaged accounts like IRAs or 401(k)s to minimize tax liability. Investment constraints: Finally, investors may face investment constraints that limit their ability to allocate their portfolios in certain ways. For example, a pension fund may be required to allocate a certain percentage of its portfolio to bonds to meet its obligations.  Overall, the factors that affect portfolio allocation are numerous and complex, and investors should carefully consider each factor when constructing their portfolios. A social media campaign is a coordinated marketing effort that uses one or more social media platforms to reinforce or assist with a business goal. Campaigns differ from everyday social media efforts in that they are more focused, targeted, and measurable. The goal of  competitor analysis is to equip you with insights to inform your product development and marketing decisions. The first stage in designing your social media strategy is determining your objectives. Maybe you want people to know more about your brand. Or maybe you want to create customer relationships, boost traffic to your website, sell your items, or share special deals. Choose two or three top priorities and concentrate on how you'll use social media for accomplishing them. Whatever your objectives, be sure they are SMART: time-bound, specified, measurable, achievable, and realistic. Establish your success metrics. If you wish to increase sales leads, for instance, specify a 20% increase. Establish a target number of posts per day or per week and decide how many likes, shares, or comments you want for each one if you want to increase exposure to your company or product. If your company already employs social media, evaluate how well it is currently serving your needs using the objectives and criteria you established in Step 1. Are your objectives being met? If so, you might want to think about raising the bar. If not, the moment has come to determine why. Consider the platforms you are utilising. Even if you just have a small amount of time to dedicate to social media, you don't have to be present on every single one. Finding the areas where you are most successful and concentrating your efforts there is significantly preferable. Next, evaluate whether your posts are accomplishing your goals. Do your posts reach your intended audience, or are they being ignored? Analyse your site and post traffic using analytics to see which content kinds are most and least popular. In Step 2, you will have already begun considering the platforms you want to employ. Now think about whether they fit the profile of your audience.  You'll have the most potential reach on LinkedIn. However, if you offer services to business professionals, you could wish to establish a presence on other social media. On the other hand, if you work in the interior design, fashion, or another "lifestyle" area, Pinterest or Instagram might be more fruitful. No matter how many social media platforms you join or posts you write, you won't be able to keep your audience's attention without quality content. Your material should be adapted to the platform you are using as well as reflect the general voice and market of your company. Each sort of social media has its own characteristics and demands, from online culture to the number of characters in a post. Consider where you want to place your brand. Are you trying to entertain or educate your audience? Are a blog article or white paper more likely to elicit a response from your audience than an image or infographic? The audience you're trying to reach is probably swamped with content from other businesses and your rivals. Always strive to create material that is interesting, relevant, and deserving of their attention. They won't read it if you aren't going to take time out of your busy day to do it! Remember that there are various theories regarding what functions best. It's important to observe what your successful competitors are doing on social media, including the platforms they utilise, how frequently they post, and their vocal tone. Examine their habits and modify them for your business. But test out several forms of content instead of just going with your soul on this. There is no ideal time that works for every organisation, so choosing when to post requires a great deal of subjectivity. When you post, let your audience be the driver. Determine when they are most active and likely to be interested in interacting with you by keeping an eye on their online behaviours. If your audience is international, you might want to plan postings at different times of the day to accommodate different time zones. You must also choose how frequently to post. You run the danger of "spamming" your followers and losing them if you publish too frequently. You could lose business if you don't update frequently enough to attract their attention. Trial and error is the best method to choose the proper frequency. Reduce the quantity of postings if you are posting 15 times per day and are losing followers. Post more frequently, on the other hand, if you just post once per day and don't attract followers. Consistency is crucial; posting erratically can give the impression that you're unreliable or disorganised. You can use an editorial calendar to plan out your pieces and keep track of information like deadlines, networks, content types, keywords, titles, and status. Microsoft Excel may be used to make a straightforward calendar. But the more specific your timetable, the more unified your social media plan will be. It takes time and effort to implement a social media plan, so unless you have a lot of free time, think about hiring someone to assist you. A designated social media manager or your team as a whole may be in charge of establishing and maintaining your social media presence. But whoever you involve, make sure they are aware of the type of online presence you are attempting to build and provide them with the instruction required to publish and update in your personal tone. If blogging is a part of your plan, be sure that it is written and edited by professionals; otherwise, you run the danger of damaging your brand. Making scheduled articles is only one aspect of maintaining an online presence; you also need to cultivate relationships. As a result, be sure to allot enough time to read your followers' comments and answer to them. The social media world moves quickly. It's critical that you always evaluate and reevaluate how your plan is working because what's popular now will be obsolete tomorrow. Utilise site statistics, such as Facebook Insights, to track your progress towards your objectives and see how specific postings are doing. However, resist the need to focus all of your efforts on gaining more followers, likes, and shares. High levels of engagement are beneficial, but keep your strategy concentrated on the connection between your activities and your corporate objectives. Engagement will reveal how well your material is received by your audience, but it is insufficient to generate income. Find techniques to gauge, for instance, how many leads you received from social media or how many people noticed your sponsored LinkedIn ad and visited your company website.
